title: This season of ranked is just so fucking discouraging...
body:
Every fucking game, something just goes wrong. 
-A lane hyper feeds.
- your jungle forgets smite. 
-There is a smurf on the enemy team.
-An afk.
-A troll. 
- one of your team mates has no keystone or messed up runes. 

Its just this same bullshit every fucking game, and honestly its ruining league for me.

replies.body: I could easily make it to silver (to most of u that is crap) but my team always feed when I go about 9/1 with my boy {{champion:91}}  or {{champion:163}} , and sometimes when I use {{champion:22}}
You forgot "bronze V riven main autofilled to support".
"Bronze V Riven One-Trick autofilled to support." Let's be fair here.
well riot decided to reset everyone's mmr. There were diamonds placed into silver for some reason

I think a lot of your problems stem from the fact that there is no good way to be a casual League player any more. Blind Draft is a joke that only makes sense for your first couple of weeks of LoL. Normal Draft is a (staggering) nightmare of missed ready checks, disintegrating lobbies, and power tantrums over champion and lane selection. At least if you queue for Ranked, you actually get to play LoL while you're young enough to still remember how keyboards work. Which is why so many of us casuals are now cluttering up the Ranked lanes.

Get Riot to stop acting like Ranked is the only game mode that matters, or will ever matter, and I bet things go back to the way they were a few years ago, when casual people mostly played on one field, and the serious folks mostly played on the other.

You know, this happens in every season.

Every. Season.

There's nothing about this season that makes those unfortunate happenstances less bearable than in seasons past.

As someone who has seen four seasons, i can happily(?) say this is by _far_ the worst one. I never even met an obvious intentional feeder in my first two years. Toxicity, chat spam, forum QQ have massively spiked, player morale and teamwork is incredibly low.
